sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1: Consider the metric on $\mathbb{R}^3$: $ds^{2} = dx^{2} + dy^{2} + 2dydz$. Determine the volume form of this metric at the point $(1,2,3)$.
message_2:
To determine the volume form of the given metric, we first need to find the determinant of the metric tensor. The metric tensor $g_{ij}$ is given by the matrix representation of the metric:

$g_{ij} = \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{pmatrix}$

Now, we compute the determinant of this matrix:

$\det(g_{ij}) = \begin{vmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{vmatrix} = 1 \begin{vmatrix}
1 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{vmatrix} = 1(-1) = -1$

The volume form is given by the square root of the absolute value of the determinant of the metric tensor times the standard volume form in $\mathbb{R}^3$, which is $dV = dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$. Therefore, the volume form for the given metric is:

$\sqrt{|\det(g_{ij})|} dV = \sqrt{|-1|} dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$

So, the volume form of the metric at the point $(1,2,3)$ is $dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$.
